Etymology: The Battle of Alamance which was derived from the local Native American word meaning \blue clay\" found in the Great Alamance Creek"

Origin: Caldwell County, Iredell County, and Wilkes County
Etymology: William J. Alexander, member of the legislature and Speaker of the North Carolina House of Commons
Derived from a corruption of the Delaware Indian name for the Allegheny and Ohio Rivers and is said to have meant \a fine stream\""
George, Lord Anson (1697–1762), a celebrated English admiral who circumnavigated the globe
Samuel Ashe (1725–1813), a Revolutionary patriot, superior court judge, and governor of North Carolina

Origin: Caldwell County, Mitchell County, and Watauga County
Etymology: Waightstill Avery (1741–1821), a soldier of the Revolution and Attorney General of North Carolina
Henry Somerset, Duke of Beaufort, who in 1709 became one of the Lords Proprietor
James or Henry Bertie, two Lords Proprietor of colonial North Carolina
Martin Bladen, a member of the Board of Trade

Origin: Bladen County and New Hanover County
Etymology: George I of Great Britain (1660–1727), Duke of Brunswick and Lüneburg
